newsitem.title: USA: 3M sues Microsoft over Post-It notes.
newsitem.headline: 3M sues Microsoft over Post-It notes.

text.p: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co charged Microsoft Corp with trademark infringement concerning 3M's Post-it notes, according to a lawsuit filed in Minnesota Federal Court.

In its official complaint, filed January 3, 3M charges that in its Office 97 software Microsoft "includes a software component for creating ... computer representations of repositionable adhesive notes, yellow in color ... very similar to those of 3M's POST-IT Software Notes sold under the POST-IT mark."
3M charges that this is in effect unauthorized use by Microsoft of the trademarked Post-It name and could cause confusion and mistakes which would negatively impact 3M and its product lines.
This suit seeks to stop Microsoft from using the feature and asks for unspecified damages and attorneys fees.
The company has notified Microsoft of its concern and has demanded that Microsoft stop using this feature.
3M spokeswoman Mary Auvin told Reuters that 3M felt it had no other choice when Microsoft failed to comply with 3M's requests.
She added that Post-It brand materials have annual sales in the hundreds of millions of dollars, both in paper and electronic formats.
Microsoft spokesman Mark Murray said the company was working with 3M to "clear up the misunderstanding," but executives believe the suit has no merit.

"We do not believe we have infringed their trademark in any way," he said. "We don't have a product named Post-It, we don't have a feature called Post-It, we don't use the phrase Post-It anywhere in our advertising and marketing."

He said the feature at issue was part of Office 97's Outlook personal information manager, a new feature in the best-selling application suite. The feature allows users to create an instant note by clicking on the "Notes" icon.
Office 97 goes on sale next week after a launch event in New York.
